awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Safe Disinfection and Oxygen-Level Enrichment in Recirculating Aquaculture Systems (RAS) Using Singlet Oxygen
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this STTR Phase I project is to address critical health, safety, cost and energy challenges in recirculating aquaculture system (RAS) disinfection. Growing high quality protein at larger scales cannot be done with current animal husbandry techniques without generating excessive greenhouse gas emissions. Intensive RAS technologies offer a viable alternative because they are capable of producing high quality protein with minimal impact on the environment.  Protecting the health of the fish is one of the key limitations to a more rapid growth of this industry.  This project will improve food production at scale. Furthermore, the proposed technology may be applied to drinking water.

This STTR Phase I project will advance a technology for safe and low-energy bacteria disinfection in a recirculating aquaculture system (RAS) by using a durable, low-cost method to generate singlet oxygen, an excited-state form of molecular oxygen.  Ozone and ultraviolet light are mainstay disinfectants in the fish farm industry, but they are expensive, energy-intensive and can be toxic to fish and personnel; motivating advances in safe, low-energy disinfection.  Singlet oxygen is a powerful disinfecting agent lethal to pathogens and harmless to fish and humans. The primary innovation of this project allows singlet oxygen to be generated at high efficiency without contaminating the water as it is not persistent. This project will conduct engineering studies as a function of both chemical structure and mass transport of reactants and products.  Detailed models will be developed to determine the appropriate dimensions of the disinfection system as well as understand the interactions between singlet oxygen and pathogens.  These models will be the first to couple transport phenomena with absorption/desorption kinetics in this configuration for RAS.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project developed new approaches for the disinfection of water that can be used for both Recirculating Aquaculture Systems (RAS), as well as other applications including waste water and potable water treatment. We demonstrated that gas-phase singlet oxygen can be generated from our specially-designed membranes with high optical power efficiency, using photosensitizers that are chemically stable for over 1000 hours.  The project quantitatively demonstrated that this approach is effective in a recirculating aquaculture environment, can effectively kill bacteria, and is energy efficient. Modeling approaches developed in this project can be used in other two-phase reactor designs.

When successful, this project will help increase the productivity of RAS farms, and so reduce the dependence on wild-caught fish as well as farming of fish in ocean pens, thus improving the ecological health of the oceans. The project will also help create an efficient means of producing high quality protein, thereby reducing global greenhouse gas production from less efficient protein farming practices (e.g. red meat) as well as by reducing emissions from long-distance transport of protein from farm to market.

The project has contributed to the education of six graduate students, providing them with insight into how their work can contribute to entrepreneurship as well as the public good by reducing global greenhouse gas emissions. The project has also exposed numerous high school students to how research at universities can be transferred to startup companies as well as contributes to the benefit of society.

Key outcomes:

  • Increased singlet oxygen generator system efficiency by over 100 fold from our first device to the most recent system built during this STTR project.  
  • Demonstrated singlet oxygen generation efficiency that is comparable to state-of-the art ozone generators, but without producing toxic chemicals (e.g. ozone) that can harm employee health or kill the fish being raised. A path has been clearly defined to further increase this efficiency.
  • Demonstrated photosensitizer stability by maintaining stable output of singlet oxygen for over 1000 hours of continuous illumination.
  • Developed a path to scale-up and commercialize our technology through a Joint Development Agreement with a major corporation.
  • Validated the need for this technology by speaking with numerous members of the RAS community.
  • Identified the potential for growing market size by developing water purification technologies for other applications, including home use and personal use.

 

Specific Accomplishments:

  • We designed a series of singlet oxygen generators (SOGs), building on the knowledge gained from each system. Five different SOG designs were built and tested.  Each design showed a significant increase in singlet oxygen yield per optical input power.  By continuously improving the system design, we increased the yield of 1O2 by 100 fold. This high efficiency, combined with our demonstration of >1000 hours of continuous operation validates the stability and efficacy of our system.
  • Tests with aquaculture water were conducted using samples provided by a commercial RAS facility.  Three samples were evaluated, based on the operation efficiency of this commercial system. We demonstrated two key aspects of our technology: our SOG continues to function and generate singlet oxygen in aquaculture water and our SOG improves the clarity of the aquaculture water.
  • Collaborators at CUNY demonstrated that E. coli bacteria can be killed using our experimental design. Aqueous solutions containing high concentrations of bacteria (3.5x 106 CFU/ml) were disinfected, reducing the concentration by almost 2 logs to 8 x 104 CFU/ml. These are excellent results because typical bacterial loads in aquaculture facilities are typically several orders of magnitude lower.
  • CUNY demonstrated that the incident wavelength of light does not affect singlet oxygen generation efficiency. The only factors that determine efficiency are the absorption coefficient of the photosensitizer and the overlap between the emitted wavelengths and absorption band of the PS. This finding will help select specific LEDs that increase both the electrical and optical efficiency of the system.
  • CUNY demonstrated that peroxides are generated during singlet oxygen treatment of aqueous amino acid solutions. The formation of peroxides, and their degradation to reactive oxygen species, may provide an addition mechanism for killing bacteria and extending the downstream treatment range.
  • Tufts designed and constructed a tabletop, closed-loop, recirculating system to test the SOG kinetics. The apparatus consisted of three joined test sections with flow provided by a recirculating pump and measured by a rotameter.
  • Tufts resolved bubble dynamics for the stated domain. The first bubble reached its terminal velocity at 0.25 cm/s as predicted analytically.
  • Tufts developed a Eulerian multiphase model in Ansys-Fluent to accurately capture interphase species transfer and chemical reactions and necessarily accommodate a high-volume fraction (more than 10 percent) of the dispersed phase (bubbles).

 


Last Modified: 05/02/2023
Modified by: Qianfeng Xu
